one_reviews_text: It is worth taking some time to honor your ears and see the world from a different perspective.

Bring some time, this is a slow, meditative experience featuring the audio recordings of professor John M. Hull who became blind in the middle of his life. Some of these thoughts moved me and made me think. The experience has 6 scenes, amongst them a scene in a park, a scene illustrating "panic", a scene in a house and the choir, which I enjoyed most.

Note that it does require touch controllers for some scenes, even though not stated on the store page.
Everything is pitch black when I enter the game.
it's really a must try experience if you have a VR...You won't regret it, trust me!

I was instantly captivated by this.  Very immersive, powerful and moving.  The way the visuals evolve as the narrator describes his experience is quite magical.  One of my favourite things I've ever done in VR (and I've done quite a lot!)
I really enjoyed this a lot.
Every time I launch the experience the screen is black and not loading anything. Where can I ask for support or a refund?
It doesnt say it requires touch controllers. But it does. Wish they would have stated this before i purchased as i only have a gamepad at the moment.

Stunning how they used VR to let u dive into a world you  don´t like to be in reality. I think it´s the right way and a good example why VR is so special and where of for what it could be used. VR is not just gaming, it´s a new universe.
Thank you for this beautiful and enlightening experience. As a person suffering from degenerative hearing loss I associated with many of your thoughts... wishing you peace wherever you are!

The combination of his actual recordings with the visual representations of sounds in VR felt perfectly done.  As someone with a child who lost most of her vision at 4 yrs old, this was a deeply personal experience as well.  This is definitely worth a few dollars and 15 minutes for those looking for a different type of VR journey.

This experience demonstrates VR capability of spatial audio.  You can selectively hear individual sounds depending on which way you turn your head, making for a life-like auditory experience.  It felt like a good fifteen minutes or so, was meditatively relaxing, and had a few nice interactive prompts.  Also the integration of this man's story with form-mimicking light particles was very professionally done!  Great buy!

This experience consists of 6 sections of about 3 minutes each, tacking different aspects of the experience of blindness. Mr. Hull's remarks are really insightful. Even though I almost never cry with media and stories in general, by the end of this I was crying. It's a powerful story! Absolutely worth paying for, even though it's short. Props to the dev team!

While the concept is interesting I have an issue on my system with Soundblaster Z  5.1 sound card.  I can barely hear the narration if at all.  Sound test within Windows/Creative software indicates all speakers are working properly.

His recordings are very eloquent and powerful. 
The VR experience puts you in his shoes and beautifully illustrates the message.
I'm a VR dev too and was worriend I'd be distracted by tech, 
it brought tears to my eyes.
This is the first VR experience that I have tried that made me cry. It was beautiful, insightful and above all meaningful to me.

Very interesting, immersive and emotional experience... one of the best I had so far (and I've sampled a whole lot, over the last year). On one point I actually experienced some slight panic myself (but panic wasn't the main ingredient here... its about perceiving reality in another way and going through the process). Highly recommended.
I allways become turned off when the scale isnt correct. I havent tried the whole experience because i was put off by the scaling
The wind scene is my favorite VR moment.
Very nice point of view.
